item.title: ScheduledExecutorService
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“Rixxx, post:41, topic:353610”][quote author=m.dog311 link=topic=449923.msg3305240#msg3305240 date=1281617198]
This is actually a very good way of going about processing, and I know for a fact that this is what Hyperion uses for quite a bit of its event/task handling.

[code] /**
* The logic service.
*/
private final ScheduledExecutorService logicService = Executors.newScheduledThreadPool(1);

/**
 * Submits a task to run in the logic service.
 * @param runnable The runnable.
 */
public void submitLogic(final Runnable runnable) {
	logicService.submit(new Runnable() {
		public void run() {
			try {
				runnable.run();
			} catch(Throwable t) {
				World.getWorld().handleError(t);
			}
		}
	});
}

/**
 * Schedules a task to run in the logic service.
 * @param runnable The runnable.
 * @param delay The delay.
 * @param unit The time unit.
 * @return The <code>ScheduledFuture</code> of the scheduled logic.
 */
public ScheduledFuture<?> scheduleLogic(final Runnable runnable, long delay, TimeUnit unit) {
	return logicService.schedule(new Runnable() {
		public void run() {
			try {
				runnable.run();
			} catch(Throwable t) {
				World.getWorld().handleError(t);
			}
		}
	}, delay, unit);
}[/code]

[/quote]
Never seen it in Hyperion.[/quote]Really? Because it looks a lot like your code…

Read full topic

}[/code][/quote]

item.dc:creator: @m.dog311 m.dog311
item.description:
@m.dog311 wrote:

This is actually a very good way of going about processing, and I know for a fact that this is what Hyperion uses for quite a bit of its event/task handling.

[code] /**
* The logic service.
*/
private final ScheduledExecutorService logicService = Executors.newScheduledThreadPool(1);

/**
 * Submits a task to run in the logic service.
 * @param runnable The runnable.
 */
public void submitLogic(final Runnable runnable) {
	logicService.submit(new Runnable() {
		public void run() {
			try {
				runnable.run();
			} catch(Throwable t) {
				World.getWorld().handleError(t);
			}
		}
	});
}

/**
 * Schedules a task to run in the logic service.
 * @param runnable The runnable.
 * @param delay The delay.
 * @param unit The time unit.
 * @return The <code>ScheduledFuture</code> of the scheduled logic.
 */
public ScheduledFuture<?> scheduleLogic(final Runnable runnable, long delay, TimeUnit unit) {
	return logicService.schedule(new Runnable() {
		public void run() {
			try {
				runnable.run();
			} catch(Throwable t) {
				World.getWorld().handleError(t);
			}
		}
	}, delay, unit);
}[/code]

item.title: ScheduledExecutorService
item.dc:creator: @primadude Primadude
item.description:
@primadude wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:37, topic:353610”][quote author=Rixxx link=topic=449923.msg3305102#msg3305102 date=1281603043]
To the incompetent Davidi2 who apparently knows how to add this to your own server yet encourages spoonfeeding to the community, I have included an example to be used in RSPS.
[/quote]If you think I would ever want to add this to my server, you are sadly mistaken. I would rather use Grahams event manager. And BTW - It’s a tutorial. Basically the definition IS spoonfeeding. If you wanted this to be acceptable, you should have posted it in ‘General Programming’.[/quote]

Graham’s event manager has a tendency to throw a ConcurrentModificationException due to it being inefficient at managing adding/removing the events; The ScheduledExecutorService class and Blake’s Event Executor avoids this, and manages events much more efficiently.

Graham’s event manager also uses a list to contain events, whereas Blake’s uses a PriorityBlockingQueue which is much better for queuing events.

Read full topic

If you wanted this to be acceptable, you should have posted it in ‘General Programming’.[/quote]If you think I would ever think of that, you are sadly mistaken. I would advise you to use Blake’s event manager instead. My tutorial has given the knowledge of how to apply it; further showing it in a server is spoonfeeding. Now please leave this topic as there is no more to discuss.

item.title: ScheduledExecutorService
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“LilXCj, post:34, topic:353610”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=449923.msg3304809#msg3304809 date=1281580699]

[quote author=Primadude link=topic=449923.msg3304807#msg3304807 date=1281580504]

[quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=449923.msg3304802#msg3304802 date=1281580290]

People want SERVER tutorials, not java tutorials.

Which is why all the current servers fail. They need to learn more about java first. So this is a good tutorial because of that reason.
[/quote]You don’t understand. A new person is not going to even read this, they will be like ‘This is to hard’ and look for a server tutorial.

Which is why we need to teach new users to get a basic understanding of the Java language before editing/creating a server.
[/quote]Yes, basic. Which is why I highly recommend the operator, variable tutorials etc. This is nothing that a new person would understand or use.

This is basic…it’s teaching how to use the ScheduledExecutorService to initiate something at a later time; it’s not advanced. If you actually read through the codes given, you’ll realise that there’s not much to it.
[/quote]I know it’s not advanced, but if you started coding in last week, and you saw this, do you honestly think you would use it? But still that’s not my point. The point is that it breaks the rules because it does not have anything about RSPS in it, or even how to add it to a RSPS. It isn’t explained well, and it could be done simpler.

  1. Learn JAVA
  2. Edit/Create Server.

JAVA tutorials > Server tutorials

Guess what holds more productivity than the other? JAVA tutorials.

Why are you arguing? Are you stupid?[/quote]I am NOT arguing about productivity, someone took one snippet out of ONE of my posts and changed the total argument. I don’t know why they wanted to argue about that anyway. But even in that case: Javadocs > This Tutorial

Because guess what! This is a RSPS forum! If you want to write Java tutorials and not include RSPS examples, take it over to MITB.

Read full topic

item.title: ScheduledExecutorService
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“Rixxx, post:26, topic:353610”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=449923.msg3304707#msg3304707 date=1281574046]

[quote author=John459 link=topic=449923.msg3304699#msg3304699 date=1281573051]
Davidi2 SHUT THE FUCK UP.

At least he contributed something useful to some people, unlike you.
[/quote]You have NO idea what I have contributed, so don’t make accusations.

[quote author=Rixxx link=topic=449923.msg3304689#msg3304689 date=1281572262]
Then what the hell are these tutorials for? Explaining more than what Java docs do, or demonstrating how they are applied in servers. Why don’t you go around a few Java tutorials posted here and say, “Sorry, these don’t explain more than the java docs” because all they do is explain what has been explained and also demonstrate the
use in private servers. Your argument is fail. qq more - I haven’t seen you post any Java related tutorials.
[/quote]Because most of the tutorials here are not explaining Java, they are explaining specifically how to add things to RSPS. The Javadocs don’t explain anything about RSPS specifically. The reason I only posted something like this on your thread, is because this tutorial is not about RSPS at ALL; at least not any more than the docs are. So tell me, what is the point? How is this better than the docs?
[/quote]Are you retarded or blind? There are java related tutorials which have been posted by people; but they explain what has been in java docs and also demonstration of use in servers. What do you want? Me explaining more than what java has? That’s like arguing that 1+1 is 3 even though it’s 2. BTW, you only posted 2 tutorials - none of which are java related.[/quote]Exactly! That’s my point! They demonstrate their use in servers. Yours does not any more than a javadoc would. I have read almost every tutorial in this section, and all of the good ones are well explained, and if there is a javadoc on the topic they explain it much more in-depth, or server-specific. Please calm down.

BTW - I’ve written over 5 tutorials here, and I frequently help people in PM and in the help section. And you sound as if writing Java tutorials makes them better, when it does the opposite. People want SERVER tutorials, not java tutorials.

Read full topic

Why don’t you go around a few Java tutorials posted here and say, “Sorry, these don’t explain more than the java docs” because all they do is explain what has been explained and also demonstrate the
use in private servers. Your argument is fail. qq more - I haven’t seen you post any Java related tutorials.[/quote]Because most of the tutorials here are not explaining Java, they are explaining specifically how to add things to RSPS. The Javadocs don’t explain anything about RSPS specifically. The reason I only posted something like this on your thread, is because this tutorial is not about RSPS at ALL; at least not any more than the docs are. So tell me, what is the point? How is this better than the docs?

EDIT - So here are the ‘Rules and Regulations’ you are breaking:

[quote=“Taharok, post:1, topic:265742”]When Posting a New Tutorial
When you are posting a new tutorial, be sure that it covers all of the following:

[ul][li]It’s a tutorial relevant directly to RuneScape 2 Private Servers and nothing else.[/li]
[li]Any code snippets provided have been thoroughly explained with careful detail.[/li]
[li]You may post a tutorial that has already been created if and only if it surpasses any existing tutorials of its type.[/li][/ul][/quote]
If you were to give a real server example, and explain what everything did, you would not be breaking any of those rules, because 1. It would be related to RSPS, 2. It would be explained, and 3. It couldn’t be compared to the JavaDocs because it would not be the same type of tutorial.

I would also like to point out that the example you made is more complicated than the one in the JavaDocs.

Read full topic
